questions.text: The most common cause of myopia is:

options.label: A
options.text: Increase in length of the eyeball

options.label: B
options.text: Increase in thickness of the lens

options.label: C
options.text: Increase in viscosity of aqueous humour

options.label: D
options.text: Increase in viscosity of vitreous humour

questions.correct_answer: A. Increase in length of the eyeball
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Increase in length of the eyeball Myopia or short-sightedness : That form of a refractive error where parallel rays of light come to focus in Front of the retina when the eye is at rest. As there is an increase in the refractive power of the eye, the near objects (closer Than 6m) will be seen normally, while far objects (whose rays come parallel) will Be focused in front of the retina.

Highyeild:

Myopia or short-sightedness: That form of a refractive error where parallel rays of light come to a focus in front of the retina when the eye is at rest. As there is an increase in the eye's refractive power , the near objects (closer than 6m) will be seen normally, while far things (whose rays come parallel) will be focused in front of the retina.

Explanation for incorrect options:- Option: B .Axial myopia : anteroposterior length is longer than normal. Option: C .Curvature myopia : increased curvature of the cornea or one or both lens surfaces. Option: D .Index myopia : increased refractivity of the lens, e.g. nuclear sclerosis (the stage before nuclear cataract), due increase in the difference between refractive indices of the nucleus and cortex.

Extraedge:

Clinical classification: Simple (stationary) : < 6D, after the age of 4y, stationary (stops before 20y), Normal physiological process and can be corrected. Pathological (progressive) : >6D, before the age of 4y, progress even after age Of 20y, a real pathological process cannot be corrected as the real pathological. The process is still found (if the patient has myopia of 20D, even if we give glasses. With -20D, he will still have refractive error)

questions.text: Which is the most common complication of pathological myopia?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Retinal detachment The most common complication of myopia is macular degeneration, followed by rhegmatogenous retinal detachment. The most common cause of rhegmatogenous retinal detachment is pathological myopia.

questions.text: In senile nuclear cataracts, what type of myopia is seen?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Index myopia In the early stages , progressive hardening of the lens nucleus causes an increase in the refractive index of the lens, causing a myopia shift . Index myopia: increased refractivity of the lens , e.g. nuclear sclerosis (the stage before nuclear cataract), due increase in the difference between refractive indices of the nucleus and cortex.

questions.text: Scarpa's Staphyloma is seen in which of the following?
questions.explanation:
Solution:

Myopia The presence of posterior staphyloma (Scarpas Staphyloma) is pathognomonic of pathologic myopia . Posterior staphyloma occurs in high myopia (axial length >26 mm) due to progressive anteroposterior elongation of the globe over time with scleral thinning in the posterior pole.
